questions.question_text: Which VPNs must be configured outside the workflow to complete the SD-WAN overlay setup when using the Quick Connect workflow?

discussion.content:
Option A. Check the restriction for quick connect workflow section in below link.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/sdwan-xe-gs-book/m-quick-connect-workflow.html

Selected Answer: A
Restrictions for Quick Connect Workflow

 The Quick Connect workflow is limited to configuring WAN settings (VPN 0). To be able to complete the Cisco Catalyst SD-WAN overlay bring up process, you also need to configure service-side VPN templates.

 For detailed information about configuring network interfaces, see Configure Network Interfaces.

 The Quick Connect workflow is supported for Cisco Catalyst SD-WAN Device (IOS XE) devices only.

 The Quick Connect workflow supports creating day-0 configurations for a maximum of 25 devices at a time. If you have more than 25 devices, run the workflow more than once, as applicable.

 You can have only one in-progress workflow at any given point.

Selected Answer: A
Restrictions for Quick Connect Workflow
The Quick Connect workflow is limited to configuring WAN settings (VPN 0). To be able to complete the Cisco Catalyst SD-WAN overlay bring up process, you also need to configure service-side VPN templates.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/sdwan-xe-gs-book/m-quick-connect-workflow.html
Option A is the correct option as per the question since the tloc ip of Rome is 10.1.1.102
In question it says, Which policy configuration must be applied in the outbound direction toward Rome? Outbound policy they are talking about, not the traffic.

Selected Answer: A
Correct option A

comments.content: Agreed, this tripped me up at first!

discussion.content: I agree A, the question is misleading it states ' outbound "toward" Rome therefore from Paris back to Rome

Selected Answer: A
A option seems correct.

choices.C: Each tenant requires two vBond controllers for redundancy.
choices.D: Each tenant requires a dedicated vBond controller.
choices.A: One vBond controller is shared between the tenants.
choices.B: Multitenancy deployment requires three vBand controllers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Probably A:

Cisco vBond Orchestrators serve WAN edge devices of multiple tenants as the devices are added to the overlay network.

Selected Answer: A
With Cisco SD-WAN multitenancy, a service provider can manage multiple customers, called tenants, from Cisco vManage.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/system-interface/vedge-20-x/systems-interfaces-book/sdwan-multitenancy.html

comments.content:
That's going to be just right.

From the link you provided:
The service provider accesses Cisco vManage using a domain name mapped to the IP address of a Cisco vManage cluster and manages the multitenant deployment. Each tenant is provided a subdomain to access a tenant-specific Cisco vManage view and manage the tenant deployment. For example, a service provider using the domain name managed-sp.com, can assign tenants Customer1 and Customer2 the subdomains customer1.managed-sp.com and customer2.managed-sp.com and manage them on the same set of Cisco SD-WAN controllers, instead of providing each customer a single-tenant setup with a dedicated set of Cisco SD-WAN controllers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I'll go with A.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Qdquq_aU84

questions.question_text: How many vBond controllers must be installed when vManager is installed in a multitenancy environment for four tenants?

choices.B: full control of the data plane and the control plane

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Greater control over SD-WAN elements when run over the company network.

https://www.teldat.com/blog/sd-wan-cloud-based-on-premise/#:~:text=Key%20advantages%20of%20an%20SD,applications%20(simplifying%20network%20management).
